events.transcript:
Meeting Transcript 1 - Operational Check-in
Date: September 15, 2024
Duration: 35 minutes
Participants: John (Vendor - CS), Jenny (Vendor - Technical), Adam (Customer - Head of CS), Smeagol (Customer - Call Center Rep), Deagol (Customer - Call Center Rep)

John: Hey everyone! Good to see you all. How's everyone doing?
Adam: Doing well, John. Thanks for setting this up.
Deagol: Hey! Yeah, all good here. Smeagol and I were just talking about how much easier tracking has gotten.
Smeagol: Yes, yes! Much better than the spreadsheets, precious... I mean, the old system we had.
Jenny: laughs I love the enthusiasm, Smeagol! And hey Adam, how was that conference you mentioned last time? The customer experience summit?
Adam: Oh man, it was actually really valuable. Picked up some good ideas about scaling our support team. Actually makes me think about how we're using Prancing Pony - I'll want to talk about that later.
John: Perfect, we definitely want to hear that. Deagol, I saw your team's activity metrics - looks like you guys are really leaning into the platform. What, like 40 customer relationships logged now?
Deagol: Yeah, 43 as of this morning actually. We've been pretty diligent about logging every significant interaction. It's become part of our daily routine now.
Smeagol: I log everything! Every call, every email thread, every complaint. The summaries help so much when we need to remember what happened with Mr. Henderson or the Jacobson account.
John: That's exactly what we love to hear. So tell me more - how are you actually using it day to day? Like, walk me through your workflow.
Smeagol: Okay, okay. So when I get a call from a customer - let's say Mrs. Patterson calls about her billing issue - I open her relationship page first thing. I can see the history, see that she called twice last week about the same thing, see that Deagol promised her a follow-up.
Deagol: Right, and that's been huge. Before Prancing Pony, we'd have to dig through Slack messages or our old notes to figure out context. Now it's just... there.
Jenny: Are you using the sentiment flags at all? Or mostly just the transcript summaries?
Deagol: Honestly, both. The sentiment flags are great for my morning prep. I filter by "negative" or "critical" and those are the accounts I prioritize for proactive outreach. The summaries help me understand the specifics without re-reading entire call transcripts.
Smeagol: The search is good too! When Mrs. Patterson mentioned her nephew had a similar problem, I searched "Patterson family" and boom - found the related account in seconds.
Adam: Yeah, they've really taken to it. I'm impressed with the adoption rate, honestly. Usually when we roll out new tools there's more resistance.
John: That's great to hear. Any pain points? Things that are clunky or missing?
Smeagol: Hmm... not really pain points, but sometimes I wish I could see multiple customers at once. Like, compare them.
Adam: Actually, that's exactly what I wanted to talk about. We're at a point now where the individual relationship tracking is solid, but I need the 30,000-foot view. I need reporting.
Jenny: Okay, tell me more about that. What kind of reporting are you thinking?
Adam: So right now, Smeagol and Deagol are managing about 40 relationships each. That's great. But as their manager, I need to see patterns across all 80+ relationships. I need to know: what percentage are trending negative? Which industries or customer segments are happiest? Are there common complaints showing up?
John: That makes total sense. You're trying to identify systemic issues versus one-off problems.
Adam: Exactly. And I need to report up to Morwen, our CEO. She wants to know if customer sentiment is improving quarter over quarter. Right now I'm basically manually reviewing the accounts and taking notes, which defeats the purpose of having this system.
Jenny: Got it. So you're thinking dashboards, trend lines, maybe some filtering and segmentation capabilities?
Adam: Yes! I want to be able to filter by date range, by rep, by sentiment. I want to see a chart showing sentiment distribution. I want to export data for board presentations. That kind of thing.
Deagol: Oh, and it would be cool if we could tag accounts by industry or customer tier. Like, our enterprise customers versus small businesses.
Jenny: These are great inputs. Let me ask some discovery questions so we can scope this properly. When you say "sentiment over time," are you thinking you want to see how a single customer's sentiment changes across multiple interactions?
Adam: Yes, both that and the aggregate. I want to see if the Jacobson account is getting more frustrated over time, but I also want to see if all our enterprise accounts are trending negative, for example.
Jenny: And for the filtering - you mentioned by rep, by date, by sentiment. What about by product line or issue type? Do you categorize your customer relationships that way?
Adam: We don't currently, but we probably should. Most of our customers are using either our Standard plan or our Premium plan. It would be useful to see if Premium customers are happier or if they have different pain points.
Smeagol: Sometimes we also track whether it's a billing issue versus a technical issue versus just a general question.
Jenny: Okay, so maybe we need to add some metadata fields to the relationship records - plan type, issue categories, things like that - and then make those available as filters in reporting.
Adam: Yeah, that would be ideal. And then I can slice and dice the data however I need.
John: This is super helpful, Adam. I'm taking lots of notes here. Jenny, what do you think in terms of feasibility?
Jenny: Definitely doable. This is the natural evolution for your use case. You've gotten the data entry part down, now you need the insights layer. I'll need to work with our product team to spec this out and give you a realistic timeline.
Adam: How long are we talking? Weeks? Months?
Jenny: Let me not speculate right now - I want to do this right. But I'll come back to you with a concrete plan at our next meeting. Can we schedule something in two weeks?
John: Yeah, let's get that on the calendar. We'll come back with an implementation plan, timeline, and probably some mockups so you can see what we're thinking.
Adam: Sounds good. I appreciate you taking this seriously. Morwen's been asking about this stuff, so it's becoming a higher priority for us.
John: Absolutely. Customer success reporting is critical - we get it. We'll put together something solid for you.
Deagol: In the meantime, we'll keep doing what we're doing. The core system is working great for us.
Smeagol: Yes, yes, very helpful, precious system!
Jenny: laughs Love it. Alright, we'll reconnect in two weeks with a plan. Thanks everyone!

Date: September 29, 2024
Duration: 25 minutes
Participants: John (Vendor - CS), Jenny (Vendor - Technical), Adam (Customer - Head of CS), Smeagol (Customer - Call Center Rep), Deagol (Customer - Call Center Rep)

John: Hey team! Good to see everyone again. How's it going?
Adam: Busy couple of weeks. Looking forward to hearing what you've put together.
Deagol: Yeah, we're curious about the reporting stuff!
Smeagol: Very curious, yes!
Jenny: Well, we've been working on it. Let me share my screen... okay, can everyone see this?
Adam: Yep, got it.
Jenny: Great. So we took everything you said last time and worked with our product and engineering teams to create an implementation plan. Let me walk you through what we're proposing.
First, we'll add custom metadata fields to the relationship records - plan type, industry, issue category, customer tier. That's phase one, probably takes about three weeks to build and test.
Adam: Okay, following so far.
Jenny: Phase two is the reporting dashboard itself. We're planning three main views: a summary dashboard with key metrics and sentiment distribution, a trends view showing sentiment over time with filtering capabilities, and a detailed export function for your board presentations. This is the heavier lift - we're estimating six to seven weeks for development.
Deagol: That sounds pretty comprehensive.
Jenny: Phase three is refinement based on your feedback. We'll roll it out to you in beta, you'll use it for a couple weeks, and we'll make adjustments. That's another two to three weeks. So all in, we're looking at about twelve weeks, or roughly three months, to get this fully deployed.
Adam: pause Three months?
Jenny: That's our realistic timeline for doing this right - quality engineering, proper testing, making sure it integrates smoothly with the existing system.
Adam: Okay, I need to be straight with you. Three months is... that's going to be a problem.
John: Talk to us, Adam. What are you thinking?
Adam: I'm thinking that Morwen, our CEO, asked me about this reporting two weeks ago. I told her you were working on it. She's going to ask me again next week. If I tell her three months, that's not going to go over well.
Jenny: I understand the urgency, but—
Adam: Look, I appreciate the thorough approach, but can we find a way to get something out faster? Even if it's not all the bells and whistles?
John: What kind of timeline were you hoping for?
Adam: I need something within a month. Even if it's a basic version, I need to show progress.
Jenny: A month is... that's going to be tight. We'd have to cut significant scope.
Adam: What if we skip phase three? Or simplify phase two?
Jenny: If we simplify phase two, you're basically getting a bare-bones dashboard with limited filtering. It might not actually solve your problem.
Adam: But it's something. Right now I have nothing to show Morwen. And I'm telling you, she's not going to wait three months.
Smeagol: Is the reporting that urgent? We're still using the system fine for our daily work.
Adam: It's not about daily work, Smeagol. It's about strategic visibility. Morwen needs to see metrics. The board needs to see metrics. Three months in business time is forever.
Deagol: I mean, I get it. Adam's been manually compiling reports and it's taking him hours.
Adam: Hours that I don't have. And honestly, the fact that we're three months away from basic reporting functionality is concerning. This is pretty standard stuff for a customer relationship platform.
John: You're absolutely right, Adam. Let me and Jenny take this back internally. We need to look at what we can realistically accelerate.
Jenny: Yeah, let me talk to our engineering lead. Maybe there's a way to get phase one and a simplified phase two out faster if we reprioritize some other work.
Adam: I appreciate that. I really do. But I need you to understand - this isn't just a nice-to-have anymore. Morwen's asking for results. If we can't demonstrate value at the management level, it doesn't matter how much Smeagol and Deagol love the tool.
John: Understood. That's a fair point. We don't want to be in a position where the end users are happy but leadership isn't seeing the ROI.
Adam: Exactly. And look, we like Prancing Pony. We want this to work. But I need you to meet me somewhere in the middle on timeline.
Jenny: Okay. Give us a week to regroup internally. We'll come back with options - maybe a phased rollout where you get something basic quickly and then we enhance it over time.
Adam: That sounds better. I can work with incremental improvements as long as we're moving.
John: We'll make this happen, Adam. Let's schedule a follow-up for next week and we'll have a revised plan.
Adam: Sounds good. Sorry to be pushy, but I'm getting pressure from above.
John: No, we get it. This is important. We'll figure it out.
Smeagol: We'll keep using the system like normal!
Jenny: Thanks, Smeagol. Alright everyone, we'll reconnect next week with a better plan.

events.participants: Adam, Deagol, Jenny, John, Morwen, Smeagol
events.transcript:
Date: October 13, 2024
Duration: 40 minutes
Participants: John (Vendor - CS), Jenny (Vendor - Technical), Adam (Customer - Head of CS), Smeagol (Customer - Call Center Rep), Deagol (Customer - Call Center Rep), Morwen (Customer - CEO)

John: Good morning everyone. I see we have—oh, hi Morwen! Thanks for joining us.
Morwen: Hi John, Jenny. I wanted to sit in on this one. Adam's been keeping me updated, but I wanted to hear directly from you where we are with the reporting functionality.
Jenny: Of course, we're glad you're here. We were just about to—
Morwen: Let me jump in before you start, if that's okay. I want to be very direct about where we are as a business. We implemented Prancing Pony four months ago. Smeagol and Deagol have done a great job adopting it at the individual level. But we're now at a point where we need strategic visibility. I need to walk into board meetings and investor calls with data about our customer health. Right now, I don't have that.
Adam: Morwen's been asking me for trend reports, sentiment analysis across our portfolio, that kind of thing. I've been telling her it's coming, but...
Morwen: But it's not here yet. And from what Adam told me, we're still weeks away?
John: Morwen, we completely understand the urgency. We've been working on—
Morwen: John, I need to be blunt with you. We're evaluating alternatives. There's a competitor called Orthanc that has all of these reporting features built in. They've been reaching out to us. I don't want to switch vendors - switching is expensive and disruptive - but I need you to understand that this isn't optional for us anymore.
Jenny: We absolutely understand. We've been—
Morwen: Do you? Because from my perspective, we've been patient. We've been good partners. We gave you feedback about what we need, and we're still waiting. How long am I supposed to wait?
Adam: Morwen, they're working on it. They had a plan for—
Morwen: A three-month plan, Adam. Three months. We don't have three months. Our Q4 board meeting is in six weeks. I need to show them customer health metrics. What am I supposed to do?
John: Morwen, what if we committed to getting you something functional within two weeks?
Morwen: Two weeks? Can you actually deliver that?
Jenny: We can deliver a working reporting dashboard in two weeks. It won't have every feature we originally scoped, but it will give you the core functionality - sentiment distribution, trend tracking, filtering by rep and date range.
Morwen: What about industry segmentation? Export capabilities?
Jenny: Export capabilities, yes. Industry segmentation might need to come in a follow-up release, but we can have the basic tagging infrastructure in place so you can start categorizing accounts manually if needed.
Adam: Wait, I want to make sure we're not setting ourselves up for failure here. If you rush this in two weeks, what's the quality going to look like? Are we going to have bugs? Is it going to be stable?
Jenny: That's a fair concern, Adam.
Adam: Because the last thing I need is to roll out a half-baked reporting tool and have it crash during a board presentation. That's worse than not having it at all.
John: Adam, Jenny and I will personally QA this before it comes to you. We'll make sure it's production-ready.
Morwen: I appreciate the commitment, John, but Adam's question is valid. How are you going to ensure quality with such a compressed timeline?
Jenny: We'll focus on core, well-tested functionality. We're not going to build new, experimental features. We'll use existing components from our platform and adapt them for your reporting needs. The underlying data infrastructure is already solid - we're really just building a new view on top of it.
Morwen: Okay. But I need to be clear about something. This is non-negotiable. We need reporting functionality. If we don't have it in two weeks, I will make the decision to evaluate Orthanc seriously. I don't want to do that - I believe in your product - but I have a responsibility to our investors and our business.
John: We understand completely, Morwen. We will deliver this in two weeks.
Morwen: And it will work? It will be usable?
Jenny: Yes. You'll be able to see sentiment trends, filter your customer base, and export data for presentations. That's our commitment.
Morwen: Alright. I'm going to hold you to that. Adam, I want you to coordinate closely with them and test this thoroughly before we rely on it for anything important.
Adam: Absolutely. Jenny, I'll want to see a demo as soon as you have something, even if it's rough. I don't want to wait until day 14 to discover there are issues.
Jenny: Agreed. We'll show you incremental progress. How about a checkpoint at day 7?
Adam: That works. And I'll want to do user acceptance testing on day 10, so we have time to catch issues.
John: We'll make it happen. Morwen, we really appreciate your directness here. It helps us prioritize correctly.
Morwen: I'm not trying to be difficult, John. I like working with you. But I can't run my business on promises. I need tools that work.
John: Understood. And you'll have them.
Morwen: exhales Okay. Good. I'm sorry to be intense, but this is important.
Adam: It is. And we appreciate you joining the call. Smeagol, Deagol - anything you want to add? You've been quiet.
Deagol: No, I mean, we're just using the system day-to-day. It's been working well for us.
Smeagol: Yes, yes. We track all our customers, take notes, everything is good. We don't really need the fancy reports, but we understand Adam does.
Morwen: And that's fine. You're doing great work. This isn't about you two - you're using the tool exactly as intended. This is about me needing to see the big picture.
Deagol: Makes sense. We'll keep doing what we're doing.
Morwen: Good. Adam, keep me posted on the day 7 checkpoint. I want to know if they're on track.
Adam: Will do.
Morwen: John, Jenny - I'm counting on you.
John: We won't let you down.
Morwen: Okay. I need to jump to another meeting. Thanks for your time.
[Morwen drops off the call]
Adam: Well, that was... intense.
John: No, she's right to push. We need to deliver.
Adam: Just make sure you do, okay? Because if this doesn't work, I don't know if we can salvage the relationship.
Jenny: We hear you, Adam. We're on it.
Deagol: Do you guys need anything from us? Like testing or feedback?
John: Just keep using the system like you have been. The more data you log, the better the reports will look when we turn them on.
Smeagol: We can do that! We're very good at logging, yes we are.
Adam: Alright. I'll be in touch later this week to schedule that day 7 checkpoint. Let's make this work.
John: Absolutely. Thanks everyone.

Date: October 27, 2024
Duration: 45 minutes
Participants: John (Vendor - CS), Jenny (Vendor - Technical), Adam (Customer - Head of CS), Smeagol (Customer - Call Center Rep), Deagol (Customer - Call Center Rep)

John: Hey everyone, thanks for making time. We're excited to show you what we've built.
Adam: I'll admit, I'm cautiously optimistic. The demo you showed me at the day 7 checkpoint looked promising, but let's see the full thing.
Jenny: Fair enough. Let me share my screen. Okay, everyone seeing this?
Deagol: Yep, we can see it.
Jenny: Perfect. So, welcome to the new Prancing Pony Reporting Dashboard. This is what you'll see when you log in and click the new "Reports" tab in the navigation.
John: We've focused on three core capabilities: overview metrics, trend analysis, and data export. Jenny, walk them through it.
Jenny: Sure. So at the top here, you've got your key summary metrics. Total relationships tracked - you can see you're at 87 now. Sentiment distribution shown both as a chart and as percentages. Right now you're sitting at 62% positive, 28% neutral, 8% negative, and 2% critical.
Adam: Okay, that's immediately useful. That's what Morwen's been asking for.
Jenny: Below that, you've got your trend line. This shows sentiment over time. You can see here there was a dip in early October - a few accounts went negative - but it's recovered since then.
Deagol: Oh wow, I can see when Mrs. Patterson was really upset. That spike of red there.
Smeagol: And when we fixed her issue, back to green!
Jenny: Exactly. Now, let's talk about filtering. Up here you can filter by date range, by rep, by sentiment, and by the tags you've added. Adam, I know you wanted to segment by customer tier and plan type - you can do that here. See these dropdowns?
Adam: And this pulls from the tags we've been adding to accounts?
Jenny: Correct. So if you want to see only your enterprise customers, you select "Enterprise" here. If you want to see only Premium plan customers, you do that here. You can combine filters too.
Adam: Show me that. Filter for enterprise customers on the Premium plan in the last 30 days.
Jenny: [clicking] There you go. Looks like you have 23 enterprise Premium customers. Sentiment is... mostly positive, one negative.
Adam: That's the Jacobson account. Yeah, we're working on that. Okay, this is good. What about export?
John: Good question. Show him, Jenny.
Jenny: This button here - "Export Report." Click that and you get options. You can export to CSV for detailed analysis in Excel, or you can export to PDF for presentations. The PDF includes all your current filters and generates nice charts.
Adam: So I could take this filtered view - enterprise Premium customers - and export a PDF for Morwen?
Jenny: Exactly. Want to try it?
Adam: Yeah, let's do it.
Jenny: [clicking] Processing... and there's your PDF. Clean, professional, ready for a board deck.
Adam: This is... this is actually exactly what I needed. Okay, I'm impressed.
Deagol: Can we use this too? Or is it just for managers?
Jenny: You can absolutely use it. You can filter by your own name and see your personal portfolio stats. It's available to everyone with a Prancing Pony account.
Smeagol: Oooh, I want to see my stats!
John: We figured everyone could benefit from seeing their own trends. It's not just a management tool.
Adam: Okay, let me ask some detailed questions. Can I see sentiment for a specific customer over time? Like, if I want to track the Jacobson account month by month?
Jenny: Good question. Click into any account from this table view... [clicking] ...and you'll see the individual relationship page. Down here is a mini trend line showing that specific customer's sentiment history.
Adam: Perfect. What about comparing customers? Can I see two side by side?
Jenny: Not in this version, but we can add that. Add it to the feedback list.
Adam: Will do. What about alerts? Like, if an account goes critical, can I get notified?
John: Not yet, but that's on our roadmap for the next quarter. We wanted to get the core reporting to you first, then we'll layer on alerting and notifications.
Adam: That's fair. Okay, Smeagol, Deagol - try clicking around. Tell me if this makes sense to you.
Smeagol: [pause] Yes, yes, I can see all my customers! Look, this one is happy, this one is sad...
Deagol: Yeah, this is pretty intuitive. I like the color coding. Makes it easy to see at a glance who needs attention.
Adam: Can you export your own reports?
Deagol: [clicking] Yep, export button works for me too. Nice.
Adam: Okay. I'll be honest, I'm pleasantly surprised. This is solid. My main concern now is stability. We pushed you hard on timeline - I want to make sure we didn't sacrifice quality for speed.
Jenny: That's a very reasonable concern. We've run extensive internal testing. John and I personally tested every feature. Our QA team did a full regression pass. But you're right to be cautious.
John: What we'd recommend is that you use this for the next week internally - test it with your team, put it through its paces - before you present anything to Morwen or use it in high-stakes scenarios.
Adam: That's smart. I'll have Smeagol and Deagol hammer on it this week. If they find issues, we'll report them immediately.
Jenny: Please do. We'd rather catch bugs now than have you discover them in a board meeting.
Adam: Agreed. What's your support process if we do find issues?
John: You have my direct line. You have Jenny's direct line. If something breaks or doesn't work right, you tell us immediately and we'll treat it as priority one.
Adam: Okay. And what about future enhancements? You mentioned alerting. What else is coming?
Jenny: We've got a roadmap session scheduled for next month. We'll want your input. Some ideas we're already thinking about: automated insights - like, the system tells you "Your enterprise segment is trending negative" without you having to discover it yourself. Comparative analysis - benchmarking your sentiment against anonymized industry averages. And deeper integration with your CRM so the data flows automatically instead of manual entry.
Deagol: Ooh, CRM integration would be great. We use Salesforce and sometimes we're duplicating data entry.
Jenny: Noted. We'll prioritize that.
Adam: I think my biggest piece of feedback is just... this feels rushed. And I don't mean that as criticism - I pushed you to rush it. But I worry there are edge cases or bugs we haven't found yet.
John: Can I be honest with you, Adam?
Adam: Please.
John: You're right. This was a compressed timeline. We had to make some trade-offs. There are probably rough edges we haven't found. But we made a commitment to you and to Morwen, and we wanted to deliver something functional that solved your core problem. We're not walking away now - we'll be supporting this actively and fixing issues as they come up.
Adam: I appreciate the honesty. And I appreciate that you delivered at all. A lot of vendors would have just made excuses.
Jenny: We take our commitments seriously. And frankly, we should have prioritized reporting sooner. You were right to push us.
Adam: Well, let's see how it holds up under real use. I'm going to run some reports this afternoon and prep something for Morwen. If it works well, I'll schedule a demo for her later this week.
John: That sounds perfect. And please, any feedback at all - big or small - send it our way.
Smeagol: I like it! Very shiny, very useful!
Deagol: Yeah, I think this will be helpful for our weekly team meetings. We can pull up the dashboard and review our stats together.
Adam: Good idea, Deagol. We should do that. Alright, I think we're good here. Thank you both for pulling this together. I know it was a lot of pressure.
Jenny: That's what we're here for. We're invested in your success.
John: Absolutely. Let us know how the testing goes this week, and we'll check in on Friday to see if you've found any issues.
Adam: Sounds good. Talk to you all soon.

summary_json.tldr: The meeting focused on the successful adoption of the Prancing Pony platform by the customer support team, with discussions on the need for enhanced reporting capabilities to track customer sentiment and relationships more effectively. Action items include scheduling a follow-up meeting in two weeks to present a concrete plan for the requested reporting features.
action_items: Schedule a follow-up meeting in two weeks to discuss the reporting plan and timeline.
Jenny to work with the product team to scope out the requested reporting features.
Prepare mockups for the reporting features to present at the next meeting.
summary_json.sentiment_explanation: The meeting was productive with positive feedback on the platform's adoption and usage. Participants expressed satisfaction with the current system and collaboratively discussed enhancements, indicating a strong working relationship and a focus on continuous improvement.

summary_json.tldr: The meeting focused on the timeline for delivering a new reporting feature, with the vendor proposing a three-month plan that the customer found unacceptable due to internal pressures for quicker results. The vendor agreed to regroup and explore options for a faster, phased rollout to meet the customer's urgent needs.
action_items: John and Jenny to regroup internally to explore options for accelerating the reporting feature timeline.
Jenny to discuss with the engineering lead about potentially delivering phase one and a simplified phase two faster.
Schedule a follow-up meeting for next week to present a revised plan.
summary_json.sentiment_explanation: While the meeting ended on a constructive note with a commitment to find a solution, there were clear signs of urgency and pressure from the customer, particularly Adam's statement: 'If I tell her three months, that's not going to go over well.' This indicates a level of dissatisfaction with the proposed timeline, but no explicit threats to the relationship were made.

summary_json.tldr: The meeting focused on the urgent need for reporting functionality from the vendor, as the customer, represented by Morwen, expressed frustration over delays and the potential evaluation of a competitor. The vendor committed to delivering a functional reporting dashboard within two weeks, with a checkpoint scheduled for day 7 to ensure progress.
action_items: Vendor to deliver a functional reporting dashboard within two weeks.
Coordinate a checkpoint at day 7 to assess progress.
Conduct user acceptance testing on day 10.
Customer to keep the vendor updated on any issues or feedback.
summary_json.sentiment_explanation: The customer, Morwen, explicitly stated, 'we're evaluating alternatives' and 'if we don't have it in two weeks, I will make the decision to evaluate Orthanc seriously.' This indicates significant frustration and a risk to the relationship, as the customer feels the urgency and necessity for the reporting functionality is not being met.

summary_json.tldr: The meeting focused on the demonstration of the new Prancing Pony Reporting Dashboard, which received positive feedback from the customer team. While the customer expressed concerns about the rushed timeline and potential bugs, they were impressed with the functionality and are eager to test it further before presenting it to higher management.
action_items: Smeagol and Deagol to test the dashboard internally and report any issues.
Adam to run reports and prepare a presentation for Morwen.
John and Jenny to check in on Friday for feedback on the dashboard.
summary_json.sentiment_explanation: While the overall feedback on the dashboard was positive, Adam expressed concerns about the rushed timeline and potential bugs, stating, 'I worry there are edge cases or bugs we haven't found yet.' This indicates a level of caution and concern that prevents a green sentiment rating.
